page.title: 05ELECTRONIC GAMES:HULL
page.content: Out of a sample of 50 children aged 9-11 in this inner-city area, just over 60% owned, or had access to, some form of{electronic game}in the home. The majority were the hand-held 'arcade' games such as Pacman, Astro-Wars or a bat-and-ball type game. Very few, however, played with them much once the novelty value had worn off, much preferring the commercially produced games which are played on a television screen via a {computer.} This is probably explained by three main facts: (a) the wider range of games and skill-levels, (b) the greater access children now have to computers through their schools and (c) the amount of time they already spend sitting in front of a television screen watching hired video films.
